keyTakeAways: Dozens of South Korean nationals were repatriated from Cambodia and arrested for alleged involvement in online scam operations, particularly 'pig-butchering' schemes involving cryptocurrency fraud.
The repatriation occurred via a chartered flight to Incheon International Airport and involved 64 individuals, all placed under arrest as criminal suspects.

South Korea has identified around 1,000 nationals among the estimated 200,000 workers in Cambodia’s large-scale scam operations, with many working in industrial-scale centres linked to wealthy or politically connected individuals.

The Prince Group, a Cambodian-based multinational network linked to Chinese-Cambodian tycoon Chen Zhi, is under U.S. and U.K. sanctions for operating scam centres and generating up to $30 million daily in fraudulent profits.
Chen Zhi, who is also an adviser to Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet and former PM Hun Sen, is wanted for wire fraud and money laundering and faces up to 40 years in prison.
The United Kingdom seized 19 London properties worth over £100 million linked to the Prince Group, underscoring the global reach and financial scale of the scam operations.
South Korea has banned travel to certain areas of Cambodia due to concerns about its citizens being lured into scam industries.
A South Korean college student was found dead in Cambodia in August 2025 after being kidnapped and tortured, leading to a joint investigation into criminal networks.
Online scam operations, particularly 'pig-butchering', have expanded in Cambodia since the pandemic, with tens of thousands of workers involved and significant financial losses to Western victims.
Scam operations have also proliferated in Laos, the Philippines, and Myanmar, with reports of severe abuse and imprisonment in these centres.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Dozens of South Korean nationals, including around 64 individuals, have been repatriated from Cambodia and placed under arrest for alleged involvement in large-scale online scam operations, particularly in 'pig-butchering' schemes involving cryptocurrency fraud. These operations, which have expanded since the pandemic, are linked to industrial-scale centres and are often tied to politically connected elites in Cambodia, such as Chinese-Cambodian tycoon Chen Zhi, who is also an adviser to Prime Minister Hun Manet. The Prince Group, a multinational network operating in Cambodia and neighboring countries, has been targeted by U.S. and U.K. sanctions due to its daily fraudulent earnings of up to $30 million. In a related development, a South Korean college student was found dead in Kampot province after being kidnapped and tortured, prompting a joint investigation into the criminal networks involved. South Korea has responded by banning travel to certain areas of Cambodia and launching domestic enforcement efforts, highlighting growing concerns over citizen vulnerability and human rights abuses in the region.
title: Dozens of South Koreans freed from Cambodia scam centres now home, arrested
